Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Synergy: Smart Flexible Camera Sheet: Ultra-Thin Semantic-Guided Cooperative Micro-Camera Array

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This highly interdisciplinary research addresses two fundamental challenges in image sensing and image understanding: 1) versatile camera systems in a small form factor, and 2) 3-dimensional scene and object recognition from 2-dimensional photos. These fundamental challenges are tackled together by developing a cyber-physical imaging system, called smart flexible camera sheet, which integrates an array of many micro-cameras (millimeters in size each) onto a thin substrate. The substrate has flexible geometric shape and the orientation of each camera is individually adjusted and controlled in real time via intelligent algorithms. The overall imaging system is ultra-thin and space-efficient, and can be easily mounted onto or embedded into any planar or curved surface. Hence it opens up a plethora of new civilian and military applications where surveillance and visual monitoring are required, thus bearing great commercialization potential. Example applications are: smart vehicles, smart transportation, highway safety, smart civil infrastructure, manufacturing lines, battlefield surveillance and reconnaissance, sensor networks, mobile robotics, medical facilities, and patient care.

Broader Impact: This project generates new educational opportunities for students at all levels, leading to curricular development in electrical engineering, applied physics, materials science and engineering, and computer science. An important component of the project is a strong dissemination and outreach program to reach other universities, K-12 students, teachers, parents and the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This highly interdisciplinary research addresses two fundamental challenges in image sensing and image understanding: versatile camera systems in a small form factor, and 3-dimensional (3D) scene and object recognition from 2D photos. To effectively address these two fundamental challenges, a cyber-physical imaging system, called a smart flexible camera sheet, was developed, which integrates an array of many micro-cameras (millimeters to sub-centimeters in size each) onto a thin substrate. The substrate has a flexible geometric shape and the orientation of each camera can be individually adjusted in real-time via intelligent algorithms. The overall imaging system is ultra-thin and space-efficient and can be easily mounted onto or embedded into any planar or curved surface.

This project has strong intellectual merits. During this project, the team developed novel physical elements, including variable-focus micro-lens, reflective light concentrators, shape-memory nano-composite micro-actuators, and batch fabrication techniques involving hybrid substrates, to construct the camera sheet. The research team also developed novel intelligent algorithms, exploiting the multitude of cameras in the array to robustly infer the content of the images and detect and track targets of interest, to guide the coordination between cameras for advanced imaging functions. Toward this goal, a deep neural network algorithm is developed to clean up noisy multiview images into cleaned image. An intelligent algorithm is also developed to enable micro-cameras cooperatively realizing ultra-large field of view by real-time video stitching. The realized camera sheet was evaluated in both laboratory and real-world settings.

This project also possesses broader impacts. This transformative research represents a paradigm shift in the design, manufacturing, and deployment of cameras and a breakthrough in computational visual intelligence. The outcome of the research has broad potential impacts in many scientific disciplines, including electrical engineering, mechanical engineering, computer science and engineering, and materials science and engineering. The camera sheet developed could be applied in a plethora of situations where surveillance and visual monitoring are required, covering a wide range of civilian and military applications, and thus bearing great commercialization potential. In particular, since the camera sheet can be easily installed onto or embedded into almost any planar or curved surface, this technology can make a tremendous contribution to smart vehicles, smart transportation, and highway safety. This research can also make a significant contribution to research in micro-optics in optical imaging, which has wide applications in medical diagnostics, biophotonics and lab-on-a-chip technologies. This project provided ample opportunities for graduate students and undergraduate students, including traditionally underrepresented students, to be involved in frontier research related to engineering, applied physics and computer sciences. The outreach activities encouraged K-12 students to pursue scientific and engineering careers. It helped to prepare a diverse, globally competitive science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) workforce for tomorrow, with the right knowledge and skills.
